title: TIPS TO MAKE IT WORK BEST FOR YOUR FOUNDATION PHASE
description: When encountering challenging vocabulary, gently push yourself to annotate context clues and paraphrase sentences aloud to deepen understanding without creating pressure—this steady approach will build your confidence with nuanced words over time.

Incorporate a small daily writing exercise where you consciously add one or two varied transition words to your sentences, framing this as a low-stress way to enhance flow and coherence gradually rather than a high-stakes task.

Practice outlining the structure of short passages by briefly noting each paragraph’s purpose and transitions; this deliberate reflection will help you see the logical flow clearly and identify subtle shifts without feeling rushed or overwhelmed.

Visualize nonlinear function graphs before solving problems to connect abstract equations with their shapes; this calm, methodical step will help you engage more deeply with challenging concepts while maintaining your steady study rhythm.

When working on systems of linear equations, set micro-goals to translate word problems into equations step-by-step, rewarding yourself for each accurate setup to keep motivation high without adding pressure.

Approach solving systems involving linear and quadratic equations by pairing with a peer who works at a slightly faster pace for occasional collaborative problem-solving sessions; this will gently stretch your limits and boost momentum while preserving your balanced study style.
